bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Henry Hanson, June 24, 1922

div1.p: Carter writes about the history of yellow fever in South America and his research on the subject.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Henry Hanson, June 24, 1922
div1.opener:
Book
Hanson
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.,
June 24, 1922.
Dear Doctor Hanson:
div1.p:
I have received your long and very satisfactory letters of May 21st.
and 29th. and will answer them Sunday when I get time. I am sending this
because it may make a difference in catching a steamer.

In an old book, “Relation du Voyage de la Mer du Sur” by Frezier--a
French Engineer, in 1717 (the voyage being 1712: '13 and '14) he states
first that in 1713 there was a great drought at Ylo, Peru and they could
only get water by burying barrels in the sand to “receive the distalla-
tion of the earth,” that this water was bad and unhealthy and that to it
was attributed the great sickness which this year destroyed more than
half of the crews of the French vessels lying there, but--he goes on to
say--“this was really a species of peste which made itself felt about 18
leagues therefrom at Moquequa and even at Arequipa--40 leagues distant.
He does not state at what time of year this occurred, but from the drought
it should have been the fall and winter--i. e. the hot, but not the hottest
season (the Piura was dry from October 12th. to after Jan. 23rd. when I
left there.

Occurring in the hot season would seem to eliminate dysentary: aboard
ship as well as ashore makes us suspicious of yellow fever. I should think
the vessels lay too far off shore for malaria. Small-pox they would have
recognized.

Has Dr. Azayguirre any record of this peste--the name which, of course,
applies to all epidemics of the time? The same man mentioned that the Dutch
had to abandon Valdivia, which they had conquered in in 1643, on account of
scarcity of provisions and sickness --especially the deaths of their gen-
erals had so weakened them that they were compelled to retire, leaving bag-
gage and connon, when they were informed of the expedition which the Vice-

roy was sending against them. Beranger Feraud considers this a yellow fever
possibility. I don't. Too far South. The general tendency, however, of
French writers is to consider every sharp epidemic in the Americas or Africa
from Valdivia to Montreal as yellow fever.

The first definite absolutely reliable account that I can find of it on
the West Coast is La Condimene's report of it at Guayaquil in 1740, which,
he says, was “its first visitation to this place.” (They all say this of all
epidemics everywhere!) “Brought by a vessel from Panama.” La Condimene--a
great naturalist, as you know, had had the fever himself in 1735 in Marti-
nique.

I have done a lot of digging up of old records--a lot of which are not
medical. They date in America from Maya inscriptions to your article be-
fore the C. Z. Medical Society and abroad from the translation of a Tamil
MSS, alledged to be from 1500 to 3000 B. C. ascribing many diseases, in-
cluding “fevers and burnings” to the “bites of serpents and other venemous
insects,” among which, by name, are included scorpians and a number of mos-
quitoes. This last, of course, does not bear on yellow fever--simply on
the insect conveyance of disease. This has been very interesting and at
times amusing. I have written, however, very little and this has been a
hard and laborious grind. I do hate to write! but I judge that this will
not be the only thing I have done that was really an onus.

You have done a very great work--a very great work indeed--not only in
the number of lives saved in holding it back this year, but there was at
least a 50% chance of it forming a permanent focus in Peru and even had
it lasted for--say--three years the chance of reinfecting Guayaquil was
great and preventing this should be estimated at certainly an average death
rate of 100 per annum--and that for many years.

Laura, who is writing this, joins me in best remembrances to you all and
in looking for ward to seeing you on your return.
